alert.note: Alert for Richland (North Dakota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks (Northeastern North Dakota and Northwestern Minnesota)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 26 at 9:59PM CDT until April 29 at 7:00AM CDT by NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Minnesota...North Dakota... Wild Rice River (MN) at Hendrum affecting Norman County. Wild Rice River (ND) near Abercrombie affecting Richland County. Sheyenne River at Harwood affecting Cass County. Red River of the North at Drayton affecting Kittson, Pembina, Marshall and Walsh Counties. Red River of the North at Pembina affecting Kittson and Pembina Counties. Red River of the North at Oslo affecting Grand Forks, Polk, Marshall and Walsh Counties. Red River of the North at Halstad affecting Traill and Norman Counties. Red River of the North at East Grand Forks affecting Grand Forks and Polk Counties. Red River of the North at Fargo affecting Cass and Clay Counties. Sheyenne River Diversion at West Fargo affecting Cass County. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. ...FLOOD WARNING FOR SNOWMELT NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL SATURDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Wild Rice River (ND) near Abercrombie. * WHEN...Until Saturday morning. * IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, MODERATE FLOOD. City begins to mobilize. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:00 PM CDT Wednesday the stage was 11.2 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:00 PM CDT Wednesday was 11.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage early Friday morning and continue falling to 7.3 feet Wednesday evening. - Flood stage is 10.0 feet. &&
info.instruction: Safety message - Turn around, don`t drown. Don`t travel through flooded areas. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
